yaak.agent.behavior
Class Actor

java.lang.Object
  yaak.agent.Agent
      yaak.agent.behavior.Actor
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Runnable, java.io.Serializable
public abstract class Actor
extends Agent

Actor is the base actor agent for sense-reason-act operations.

Version:
$Id: Actor.java 6 2005-06-08 17:00:15Z jsmith $
Author:
Jerry Smith

Returns:

getActResult

public java.lang.Object getActResult()

Retrieves the result of the actor's act() method.

Returns:
The object produced by act().

execute

public final void execute()

Performs agent-specific operation(s). This method is executed automatically when an actor's run() method is invoked. Unlike with Agent, you cannot override this method.

There are two approaches to associating executable "behavior" with an actor:

  1. Specialize Actor, overriding one or more of the following methods:
    • sense()
    • reason()
    • act()
    which exhausts the single inheritance possibility in order to provide custom behavior. 
       ...
   class MyActor extends Actor {
     public boolean sense() {
       // sense, sense, ...
       // return true in order to continue with reason()
     }
     public boolean reason() {
       // think, think, ...
       // return true in order to continue with act()
     }
     public Object act() {
       // act, act, ...
       // return an arbitrary object, or null
     }
   }
   ...
   Actor actor = agentContext.createAgent(MyActor.class);
   ...
   new DefaultExecutor().execute(actor);
   ...
  2. Set the agent behavior for any agent, which (the default) execute() attempts to execute. 
       ...
   class MyActorBehavior implements ActorBehavior {
     public void execute() {
       // perform behavior (operations)
     }
   }
   ...
   Actor actor = agentContext.createAgent(AnyActor.class);
   ...
   actor.setAgentBehavior(new MyActorBehavior());
   ...
   new DefaultExecutor().execute(actor);
   ...

Note that, with this execution option, whether or not sense(), reason(), or act() are actually invoked is totally (1) up to the supplied behavior object, and (2) dependent (still) on (a) specializing Actor to provide sense-reason-act behavior, or (b) coding a custom sense-reason-act cycle within the behavior object (ignoring sense(), reason(), and act() within Actor). In other words, the supplied behavior provides the sense-reason-act protocol for Actor, optionally, using the actor's supplied sense-reason-act operations or supplying sense-reason-act protocol and operations of its own design.

The latter approach (setting the behavior object and specializing Actor to provide the actual sense-reason-act operations, is the default, in the sense that Actor.execute() attempts to invoke ActorBehavior.execute(Actor actor) if the agent behavior is not null.

In both code segments above, the behavior is executed via the following technique:

   new DefaultExecutor().execute(actor);

That is, the actor's operations are executed indirectly (with respect to the thread context) by handing the actor off to other functionality that establishes an execution context. It's possible, of course, to use any direct or indirect execution context, e.g.,

   // directly, within the current execution context:
   actor.run();
   // indirectly, using 'Thread' to establish an execution context:
   new Thread(actor).start();
   // indirectly, using a dedicated executor:
   new DefaultExecutor().execute(actor);
   // indirectly, using a thread-pool scheduler:
   scheduler.add(actor);

Overrides:
execute in class Agent

sense

protected boolean sense()

Performs an arbitrary, application-specific sensing operation. The default sense() is empty and returns true.

Returns:
The sensing status.

reason

protected boolean reason()

Performs an arbitrary, application-specific reasoning operation. This method is executed only if sense() returns true, essentially, an indicator of whether or not to continue the sense-reason-act sequence. The default reason() is empty and returns true.

Returns:
The reasoning status.

act

protected java.lang.Object act()

Performs an arbitrary, application-specific act operation. This method is executed only if reason() returns true, essentially, an indicator of whether or not to continue the sense-reason-act sequence. The default act() is empty and returns null.

Returns:
The object produced as a by-product of the act behavior.
